awd_titl_txt: CSR: Small: Resource Management for Real-time Cloud Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
Cloud computing enables flexible, dynamic outsourcing while improving cost efficiencies. These operational and economic benefits, however, are today not available to safety-critical and mission-critical real-time applications due to the lack of timeliness supports by current cloud infrastructures.  Providing real-time guarantees on cloud platforms faces several novel challenges because cloud platforms are not designed for response time guarantees but to achieve elasticity and the illusion of abundant resources available on demand.

This research extends current cloud infrastructures with resource management techniques to enable real-time guarantees on the cloud. The proposed work focuses on the scheduling of data-intensive real-time applications onto cloud resources to meet their timing requirements. The project (i) proposes a formal framework for modeling and performance evaluation of real-time applications in cloud environments, with a focus on data-parallel middleware; (ii) develops algorithms for scheduling continuous streams of real-time cloud applications in an online setting; (iii) designs techniques to address issues introduced by virtualization and machine failures based on probabilistic models, hierarchical scheduling techniques, multi-mode techniques, and feedback control techniques; and (v) evaluates these techniques in the context of practical real-time applications.
 
The research will result in the development of a real-time variant of at least one data-parallel middleware infrastructure by enhancing existing open-source platforms. Research prototypes will be released as open source to spur the research and development of cloud computing targeting real-time applications and systems. Research concepts and tools developed in this project will be incorporated into relevant courses at Penn.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to develop resource management techniques for real-time data-parallel cloud platforms. The project has successfully accomplished the following research activities:  (1) formal performance models and resource management algorithms for MapReduce applications; (2) scalable network resource allocations across multiple datacenters using software-defined networking (SDN) technologies; (3) resource provisioning and scheduling algorithms for network function virtualization to provide latency guarantees; (4) compositional scheduling theory for real-time virtualization and multicore systems that consider practical aspects of modern hardware such as caches and overheads; and (5) implementations of the data-parallel middleware and real-time virtualization platforms based on the techniques in (1)-(4), as well as extensive evaluation and deployment of realistic cloud-based applications.

 

The project has led to a range of formal models and an evaluation framework for MapReduce-based big-data analytics applications that enable automatic optimization of their cost and real-time performance, an SDN-based resource allocation solution an Internet-scale Layer-2 network across multiple geographically distributed datacenters, a real-time network function provisioning platform, and a series of overhead- and cache-aware interface models and analysis techniques for compositional scheduling and analysis of real-time applications on multicore and virtualization platforms. In addition, the project also partly supported the development of RT-Xen, the first real-time extension of Xen (one of the most widely-used virtualization platforms in today’s clouds) that offers timing guarantees for virtual machines and applications within virtual machines.   

 

In terms of intellectual and broader impacts, the project has advanced the state of the art in both real-time systems and cloud computing domains, pushing the foundations for compositional real-time systems and virtualization technology, as well as scheduling theories for data-intensive applications on the clouds. The integration of RT-Xen with the official Xen distribution also enables cloud users to benefit from RT-Xen's support for real-time performance and timing isolation guarantees. The outcome of the project forms a foundation for improving safety, performance and efficiency of many of the nation's critical infrastructures, such as networking and time-critical cyber-physical systems. The techniques and findings developed in this project have the potential to be applied to improving the design and safety certification of smart medical devices and systems, and smart transportation systems (e.g., self-driving vehicles) in the age of IoT, where timing performance is critical.

In terms of education impact, this project has led to one Ph.D. dissertation, and it provided research training for two doctoral students (who are close to graduation) and several master’s and undergraduate students. The work done by the PI in this project also partly helped her gain a tenure-track assistant professor position at Penn.
